meanings: (1) **eye** (pl. *ʾɛne*) | *murmə́lla ʾɛ́ne dìye* He raised his eyes, *ʾu-ʾɛ́ni-žigən hóla bṣìre*<|> My eyes have deteriorated (A24:10); *xonăwáθi θéla qam-ʾɛ̀ni*<|> My brothers have come to mind (A18:12); *rába xzìθa ʾɛ́ne díye*<|> *m-d-ò-məndi*<|> He had suffered a lot from that affair (A18:32); *garət ʾɛna* eyelid.
(2) **aperture** (pl. *ʾɛnaθa*) | in a field boundary for the introduction of irrigation water: *dwíqle ʾɛ́nət xáqla b-màssa*<|> He closed the irrigation aperture of the field with a pole.

(3) **spring of water** (pl. *ʾɛnaθa, ʾɛnăwaθa*) | *ʾɛ́na hóla nwàʾa*<|> A spring is welling up, *ʾƐ̄n-Nune* Spring of Fishes (village name), *ʾɛ́nət K̭ùtto*<|> *... ʾɛ́nət ʾùmra*<|> the spring of K̭utto *...* the spring of the church (the two water springs in ʾƐn-Nune B10:61); *ʾu-píšla rəš-ʾɛ̀na*<|> She remained at the spring (A25:57); *zílle rəš-ʾɛ̀na*<|> He went to the spring (A15:2).

(4) Idioms: *gu-d-ànna ʾɛ́ni bṱ-áθən*<|> (I promise) by these eyes (of mine) that I shall come (A22:20); *ða-ʾáqla rēš-d-àyya ʾɛ́nən*<|> *ʾu-ðá rēš-d-àyya*<|> We shall treat you with respect (literally: one leg on this eye of ours and one on this other one B9:10).

trans: **unless, only if, except, but, particle of insistence; or not** (§19.5.5.).
meanings: (1) **unless** | *b-ču-ʾúrxa ʾo-Dəmdə́ma lɛ́ šaqlìtule*<|> *ʾə́lla qăṭítula míyət Dəmdə̀ma*<|> By no means will you capture Dəmdəma unless you cut off the water of Dəmdəma (A11:17); *xə́tna lè-y-axəl*<|> *ʾə́lla qablíle xà-məndi*<|> The groom would not eat unless they pledged something to him (B10:40); *là qɛṣə́nne káwsux,*<|> *ʾə́lla ṱ-amrə́tli ʾánna ma-brinànela gu-réšux*<|> I shall not cut your hair, unless you tell me what these wounds are on your head (A29:5-6).
(2) **only if** | *ʾána míθənwa l-márya ʾalàha*<|> *ʾə́lla ṱ-aθyáwa báxta bàθri,*<|> *ṱ-azànwa*<|> I had sworn to the Lord God that only if a woman came after me would I go (A8:94).

(3) **except** | combined with a negator = only: *w-ána hon-mə́rta ṭla-Nozàli*<|> *ʾána le-gáwrən ʾə́lla xóna díya Gozàli*<|> I said to Nozali that I would only marry her brother Gozali (A8:95).
(4) **but, but rather** | *ʾu-čú bəṛ-náša la-máṭəlla ʾə́lla b-rzáyət gána-diya ṱ-àθya*<|> Nobody can reach her, but rather she comes of her own will (A8:65).
(5) **particle of insistence** | *ʾə̀lla gáwrət*<|> You must marry (A16:6); *ʾə́lla xazyánne xòni*<|> I must see my brother (A8:66).
(6) **or not** | *ʾáw lɛ́ðe čádrət bábe díyila ʾə̀lla*<|> He did not know whether it was his father’s tent or not (A28:33).

(2) **only if** | *ʾána míθənwa l-márya ʾalàha*<|> *ʾə́lla ṱ-aθyáwa báxta bàθri,*<|> *ṱ-azànwa*<|> I had sworn to the Lord God that only if a woman came after me would I go (A8:94). (4) **but, but rather** | *ʾu-čú bəṛ-náša la-máṭəlla ʾə́lla b-rzáyət gána-diya ṱ-àθya*<|> Nobody can reach her, but rather she comes of her own will (A8:65). meanings: (1) **if** | *ʾən-pálšəx mən-d-áni qaṭlìlən*<|> If we fight with them, they will kill us (A14:44); *ʾən-lá-ʾazən mšàyðən*<|> If I do not go, he will go mad (A4:27); *ʾən-kpìnni,*<|> *ṱ-axlə̀nne*<|> If I get hungry, I shall eat it (A23:5); *ʾən-íle mìθa,*<|> *gắrəg mɛ̀θən*<|> If he is dead, I must die (A8:61); *ʾən-ʾíθ pàwxa,*<|> *ʾi-marmíle gu-hàwa*<|> If there is wind, they raise it in the air (B5:97); *ʾə́n-in ʾàna ʾə́θya gu-šwíθəx,*<|> *qrɛ́gən xaddàməx*<|> If I have come to sleep in you bed, call your servants (A26:4); *máṣət ṱ-óðət rába məndiyáne mə́nne dìye,*<|> *ʾən-ila zawdàne*<|> You can make make many (other) things from them, if they are left over (B5:219). Complement of the verb ‘to wait’: *sàpri*<|> *ʾən-háwe pàwxa*<|> They wait for there to be wind (B5:97).

(2) **either/or** | *là-barya*<|> *gànwi*<|> *ʾən-sàlbi*<|> They cannot steal or plunder (A29:39); *ʾən-qaṭlə́nnux ʾáyya bráta šaqlə̀nna*<|> *ʾən-la-pálṭən m-àxxa*<|> Either I shall kill you and take this girl or I shall not go out from here (A29:28); *ʾən-ile-qṭìla,*<|> *ʾən-ile xìla*<|> He has either been killed or he has been eaten (by wild animals) (A39:17); *lɛ́la ðáʾa módi bràya,*<|> *hadíya pɛ́ša kèpa*<|> *ʾə́n la-pɛ́ša kèpa*<|> She did not know what was happening, whether she would now turn to stone or not turn to stone (A8:73).
(3) **interrogative particle** | *ʾə́n máṣət šaqlə̀tla?*<|> Can you take it? (A39:9).

trans: **hand; handle; arm; foot (of an animal); round of a game.**
meanings: (1) **hand** | *ʾíðux lá-darət gu-nùra*<|> *t-là-ʾaqða*<|> Do not put your hand in the fire, lest it burn (D2:8); *b-ʾíðe díye dawùqle*<|> He would hold it in his hand (B6:3); *zríyənwale b-iθàθi*<|> I had cultivated it with my hands (A17:32); *b-ìðən xɛṭə́xwa*<|> We would sew by hand (B10:59); *hállule l-ʾìði*<|> Hand him over into my custody (A28:25).
(2) **handle** | *ʾiðət tăra* handle of a door; *ʾiðət magreta* the handle of the shaving knife.
(3) **arm** | *dawɛ́ra ʾíðe-w ʾàqle*<|> A mule (is a man’s) arms and legs (B5:124); *šə́ryəlla ʾáqle w-ìðe*<|> He untied the legs and arms (A10:13).
(4) **foot (of an animal)** | *qímle tàwra*<|> *primále ðá ʾíðe dìye*<|> He cut off one of the feet of the ox (A22:3).
(5) **round of a game** | *kəmà ʾiθáθa mṭáləx?*<|> How many rounds shall we play?; *ṭḷà-ʾiθaθa muxsə́rre Mắmo*<|> Mămo lost three rounds (of chest) (A26:66).
(6) Idiom: *l-ʾiθàθux*<|> in your presence (A12:29).

(2) **handle** | *ʾiðət tăra* handle of a door; *ʾiðət magreta* the handle of the shaving knife. meanings: (1) interrogative particle: *ʾíman ṱ-àθət?* When will come?; *hal-ʾíma dàməx?*<|> Until when will he sleep? (A12:8); *bắyən t-yắðən ʾána ʾíman mɛ̀θena*<|> I want to know when I shall die (A16:1).

(2) Governing temporal subordinate clause: *ʾíman ṱ-àθyət,*<|> *ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx*<|> When you come back, I’ll give you another purse like that one (A4:16). *ʾiman-t >ʾimə(t)*: *ʾímət xílla ʾap-o-t-trè,*<|> *píšla xà-šabθa,*<|> *tré šabbàθa,*<|> *kpìnna*<|> When they had eaten the second one, a week, two weeks went by and they became hungry (A20:9); *ʾímə zílle kəs-màlka,*<|> *díwənt málka hóle ṃḷíθa náše ràbe*<|> When he went to the king, the audience chamber of the king was full of many people (A17:31).
raw_entry: *ʾiman, ʾima* part. **when.** (1) interrogative particle: *ʾíman ṱ-àθət?* When will come?; *hal-ʾíma dàməx?*<|> Until when will he sleep? (A12:8); *bắyən t-yắðən ʾána ʾíman mɛ̀θena*<|> I want to know when I shall die (A16:1). (2) Governing temporal subordinate clause: *ʾíman ṱ-àθyət,*<|> *ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx*<|> When you come back, I’ll give you another purse like that one (A4:16). *ʾiman-t >ʾimə(t)*: *ʾímət xílla ʾap-o-t-trè,*<|> *píšla xà-šabθa,*<|> *tré šabbàθa,*<|> *kpìnna*<|> When they had eaten the second one, a week, two weeks went by and they became hungry (A20:9); *ʾímə zílle kəs-màlka,*<|> *díwənt málka hóle ṃḷíθa náše ràbe*<|> When he went to the king, the audience chamber of the king was full of many people (A17:31).

meanings: (1) **presentative particle** | in association with verbs of perception: *ʾə́θyela xə̀zye*<|> *ʾína ṭéna kúlle ṃə́ḷya šə̀xta*<|> They came and saw that the saddle bag was completely full of filth (A7:11); *qímela zíle xə́zye ʾína dū̀s*<|> They went and saw that it was true (A14:13); *xazéle ʾína bɛ́θe ṃə̀ḷya*<|> He sees that his house is full (A21:8); *paθə̀xle tắra,*<|> *ʾína xazéle ʾo-ʾažvána tàma*<|> He opened the door and saw the caretaker there (A22:43). Implied verb of perception: *mátti bála gu-yàma,*<|> *ʾìna*<|> *ʾa-sústət yamàθa*<|> *nabòləlla*<|> *Čəlkằze*<|> They looked at the sea (and saw) the mare of the seas taking away *Čəlkăze* (A12:34); *ʾo-xabúša pθìxtəlle,*<|> *ʾína ʾisə́qθa dìya*<|> She opened up the apple and (saw) her ring (A4:19). Introducing preliminary background material: *ṭḷáθna hon-yíwtəlla mòʿəd.*<|> *ʾína ṱ-áθi làxxa.*<|> *ʾáti kúl fàtra*<|> *mṭašə́tla gánux baràye*<|> I have made an assignation with the three of them. Now, (when) they come here, each time you hide yourself outside (A22:21-22). Climactic result: *ṣléla tàma.*<|> *ʾína kúlla gɛ́rme díya šmìṭe.*<|> She went down there and all her bones were broken (A20:4). In commands: *ʾína m-báθər maqðàli*<|> *ʾaw-qə̀ṭma*<|> *šaqlìtule*<|> *mxamìtule*<|> Now, after she burns me, take the ashes and keep them (A26:85).

(2) **but** | drawing attention to something unexpected: *ʾána bắyənwa šaqlə́nwali xáčča mə̀šxa*<|> *... ta-ṱ-áxlən b-ʾùrxa*<|> *xáčča mə́šxa-w lə̀xma*<|> *ʾína ʾíði ṣéla gu-d-áwwa hə́nna lìnta*<|> I wanted to take a little oil to eat on the way, a little oil and bread, but my hand has got stuck in this thing, the pot (A23:8); *ʾə̀θyela,*<|> *plíṭe bárqul mðitèy.*<|> *ʾína mðitéy kúlla mxíθa l-kòma*<|> They came out opposite their town. But, their town was all covered in black. (A4:28). In exclamatory constructions: *ʾánna ṣàli*<|> *ʾína mò ṣáli*<|> They went and what (a surprise when) they went down! (A25:13); *xá-bena plíṭṭɛla xa-bràta.*<|> *ʾína mù-brata!*<|> Then a girl came out, but what a girl! (A13:11); *xílənna ʾína mòdi!*<|> I have eaten it, so what! (A2:11).

(3) **otherwise** | *ʾána hon-márəllux b-àyya šárṭ ʾaláha t-yawə́llux,*<|> *ʾína là-yawəllux*<|> I am telling you, God will give to you on this condition, otherwise he will not give to you (A3:5).

meanings: (1) Used without suffixes | *ʾíθən xa-ṭùra*<|> There is a mountain (A24:11); *ʾána ʾíθ šùla qámi*<|> There is work in front of me (to do) (A24:45); *hóla ʾíθən jə̀nne gáwa!*<|> There are jinn in it! (A22:33); *ʾíθwa xa-màlka*<|> There was a king (A1:2).
(2) With L-suffixes expressing possession: *ʾitle, ʾiθwale* | *ʾítli ðá bratət-màma*<|> I have a cousin (A7:17); *ʾíθwalən xa-màlka*<|> We had a king (A4:31).

(3) With pronominal suffixes attached to *b-*: *ʾiθbe, ʾiθwabe, ʾibe, ʾiwabe* | *mə́ṭyɛle xa-káwtət ʾə̀rwe,*<|> *ʾíbe tre-ṭḷáθa ʾálpa rēš-ʾə̀rwe*<|> He came to a flock of sheep, in which there were two or three thousand head of sheep (A32:14); *ʾìwabi*<|> *ʾəṣrá šə̀nne*<|> I was ten years old (B5:130); *mo-ʾìba!* What is there in it (= That is fine, OK) (A13:1).

trans: **in, at, on, with, by means of.**
annotations: rare variant *biyət*; with pfronominal suffixes, *biye, biye diye, bi-diye, ʾəbbe*
meanings: (1) Spatial and temporal location: *šqílɛle qɛ́sa b-ʾíðe dìye*<|> He took the stick in his hand (A22:30); *b-lɛ̀le* at night (A15:8).
(2) Instrument: *zríyənwale b-iθàθi*<|> I have cultivated it with my hands (A17:32).

(3) Comitative and associative: *ʾáθi b-dáwla-w zórna-w tópe-w* Let them come with the drum and pipe and with guns (A4:33); *lìtlən šúla bíye*<|> We have no business with it (= It is not our business) (A48:6).
(4) Attributive: *ʾána b-zawnə́nne ʾən-háwe b-tə́rte ʾaqlàθa*<|> I shall buy it if it has one leg (A22:9).
(5) Material: *ṱ-oðə́tli gə́šra b-qɛ̀sa*<|> Make me a bridge of wood (A17:18).
(6) Price: *xá-kilo ʾə́xre b-ṭḷáθa dàwɛle*<|> One kilo of dung sells for three gold pieces (A7:14).
(7) Manner: *maṣlɛ́lən b-iqàra*<|> They bring us down with honour (A4:30).
(8) Cause: *ʾámər b-àyyət mšúdrəlli?*<|> Was it for this (reason) you sent for me? (A21:32).
(9) Oath: *b-álaha ʾáwwa xoš-yàlɛle*<|> By God, he is a good lad (A21:5).
(10) Combined with other prepositions: *hóle də́rya jùlla b-réša*<|> He put a cloth over them (A25:48). → *bəd, bud*
raw_entry: *b-* prep. (2) Instrument: *zríyənwale b-iθàθi*<|> I have cultivated it with my hands (A17:32). (4) Attributive: *ʾána b-zawnə́nne ʾən-háwe b-tə́rte ʾaqlàθa*<|> I shall buy it if it has one leg (A22:9). (5) Material: *ṱ-oðə́tli gə́šra b-qɛ̀sa*<|> Make me a bridge of wood (A17:18). (6) Price: *xá-kilo ʾə́xre b-ṭḷáθa dàwɛle*<|> One kilo of dung sells for three gold pieces (A7:14). (7) Manner: *maṣlɛ́lən b-iqàra*<|> They bring us down with honour (A4:30). trans: **only; no more; if only; only if; but.**
meanings: (1) **only** | Governing clause constituent: *bas-yə̀mma ʾíθwale*<|> He had only a mother (A21:3); *bas-ànən šríṭa*<|> They have all been killed. Only I have escaped (B19:8); *bas-mìya máttət qam-réša díya*<|> Place only water by her head (A21:37); *bas-ʾɛ́ni t-xzéla ʾày xoš-ʾáza gu-jahànnam*<|> Only my eye, which saw it—let that go to Hell (A16:2); *ʾánna júlle dìye xə́zye bás*<|> We only found these clothes of his (A14:17).
(2) **no more** |. *mattátla xa-kawázət míya kəs-réša-w bàs*<|> Put out for her a jar of water by her head and no more (A21:10).
(3) **if only** | Clausal connective: *xuš-mɛ̀θən*<|> *bas-xáθi Nozáli xazə̀nwala*<|> Let me die, if only I could see my sister Nozali (A8:57).
(4) **only if** | *bas-ʾánna xonăwáθi bàsmi,*<|> *gorànnux*<|> Only if you cure these brothers of mine, shall I marry you (A34:22).

(5) **but** | Clausal connective: *ʾɛ́ne pθìxtɛla,*<|> *bas-ṭlìya hóle*<|> His eye is open, but he is asleep (A31:6); *lɛ̀le-xəzya čù-náša*<|> *bas-yắðəx hóla tlíxe ʾánna bàte*<|> Nobody has been seen, but we know that the houses have been destroyed (A29:52). Before a reduced predication: *ʾax-sinìyele*<|> *bas-gòṛa*<|> It is like a tray, but (it is) bigger (B6:45).

(3) **in, by** | only in fixed expressions: *hɛr-dmíxtɛla bəd-lə́bba gu-bɛ́θət bába dìyɛla*<|> She continued sleeping, thinking that she was in her father’s house (A21:18); *ʾi-banɛ́wa báte b-képa mnùjra,*<|> *mnújra bəd-ʾìða*<|> They would build houses with dressed stone, dressed by hand; *báxta hóla yaqúrta bud-yàla*<|> The woman is pregnant with a child.

meanings: (1) **more, most** | With adjectives: *ʾína mástət ʾə́rwe rába biš-basimtɛ́la biš-príštɛla mən-d-a-t-tàwre*<|> But the yoghurt of sheep is much better and more choice than that of cattle. (B5:173); *ʾaṣə́rta mɛθɛ́wala ða-dúkθa bíš-qurba t-y-awɛ́wa mìya táma*<|> In the evening they would bring them to closer place closer where there was water (B5:160); *ʾíθən ... biš-xoš-gùṛe*<|> There are better men (A26:79); *ʾíθwa lìθwa*<|> *biš-m-álaha góṛa čú-mdi lìθwa*<|> There was, there was not, there was nothing greater than God (A30:1); *qu-qálbəx bɛ́θa biš-spày*<|> Come let’s return home—(that is) better (A30:55); *múr ʾɛ̀ni-mənnən*<|> *biš-šapìrtɛla*<|> Say which of us (three) is most beautiful (A25:17); *ʾáy biš-xámθɛla m-kùlla*<|> She is more beautiful than all (= the most beautiful of all)’ (A25:26). Adjective omitted: *bíš m-áyya dúkθa ʾɛ̀ka xázəx?*<|> Where could we find (something) better than this place? (A12:5). With adverbs: *qəm-maxéla ʾáqla biš-xɛlàna*<|> He struck her leg harder (A33:12); *dráyɛle biš-hódəx mə́nna díya xáčča xàmra*<|> He put some wine further up from them (A12:49). With verbs: *xáčča biš-šlèla*<|> She became a little more calm (A4:17); *bíš madqə́rre mən-d-ó déwa ṱ-axə́lwa ʾə́rbe dìye*<|> He (God) valued him more than the wolf that ate his sheep (A10:13).

(2) **(not) at all**| intensifier of a negator: *y-amríwa ʾáw bíš la-mzànzər*<|> *yáwəl ṭéma pàyəšwa*<|> They said that it does not lose its taste at all. It keeps its taste (B10:76); *ʾáp-xa lá-biš-ile-mṣaya mqarów-əlla dìya*<|> Nobody was able to go near her at all (A4:6); *b-qɛ̀ṭa*<|> *bíš liθ-məṭràθa,*<|> *ʾu-bíš liθ-tàlga*<|> In summer there are no rains at all and there is no snow at all. → *zawda, zoda*

meanings: (1) **annexation particle introducing nominal complements of nominals** | *brónət màlka* the son of the king (A32:21); *ṭəppəryáθət heywàne*<|> the claws of animals (A19:2); *málka d-áyya bàžər* the king of this town (A32:5); *bɛ́θa d-àw* the house of that one (A8:24); *ʾan-ʾə́rwe d-ɛ̀nila?*<|> Whose sheep are those (A32:16); *diy-* when combined with pronominal suffixes: *bábe díye* his father (A32:31); *gu-máθa dìyən*<|> in our village (B2:6); predicative: *ʾáwwa bɛ́θa dìyəxile bráti?*<|> Is this house yours, my daughter? (A40:13).

(2) **relative particle introducing clausal complements of nominals** | *ʾan-suráye t-wáwa gu-Tùrkiya*<|> *zílla l-ʾÌrən*<|> The Christians who were in Turkey went to Iran (B2:8); *ʾu-ʾup-báxte dìye*<|> *ṱ-íle gwìrəlla*<|> *rába hawnàntɛla*<|> Also his wife, whom he had married, was very clever (A17:21); *ʾɛ́-šetət mɛ́θi qəm-yawə́lla xa-bróna zòra*<|> In the year they would die he gave them a small son (A4:57); *ʾo-t-̭íle wíra ʾáw xaràmɛle*<|> The one who has entered is cursed (A23:27).

(3) **introducing nominal and clausal complements of adverbs and prepositions** | *dáx páyəš málka šáwpət bròni?*<|> How will he become king in place of my son? (A8:4); *qámət gə̀ppa*<|> in front of the cave (A12:7); *ʾax-d-àwwa*<|> like him (A26:34); *báθər d-ɛ̀-maθa*<|> behind that village (A24:30); *bēl-d-áyya l-d-àyya*<|> between this and that (B5:115); *mə́ṭye l-d-o-nèra*<|> They arrived at that river (A14:58); *diy-* when combined with pronominal suffixes | *ʾax-díye* like him (A4:3); *bíye díye* with him (A14:8); *č̭ənnək̭ɛ́re díye* around him (A8:71); clausal complements: *mɛ́θən ʾax-ṱ-ila-ʾànna míθe*<|> I shall die like these people have died (A14:73); *qam-ṱ-àθi*<|> *mpáləṭle mən-hàbsa*<|> Before they return, release him from prison (A26:72); *m-bár t-y-óði núra gàwe,*<|> *xáyəm ràba*<|> After they put fire in it, it heats up a lot (B6:48).

(4) **introducing clausal complements of verbs** | *ʾánna yắði ṱ-íle duglàna*<|> They know that he is a liar (A48:3); *bắyən ṱ-àzən*<|> I want to go (A8:65); *máṣəx ṱ-àmrəx*<|> We can say (B4:3).

(5) **introducing clausal complements of clauses** | normally expressing purpose: *ʾána paqðə̀nnɛxu*<|> *ṱ-azítu b-ʾúrxa maṭítu ʾə̀lla*<|> I shall instruct you so that you go on the road and reach her (A8:27). → *t-la*

trans: **how? how could it be? like, just as; when**
meanings: (1) **how?** | *dáx ʾúrxa muxzélux ʾə́lla lípla ʾàwwa šúla?*<|> How did you show her the way to learn this work? (A21:34); *dàx-it?*<|> How are you? (A22:16); *hà bráti,*<|> *dàx-it,*<|> *dàx-lɛt?*<|> My daughter, how are you? (said after long absence) (A21:27); *dàxi?*<|> How (could this be)? (A25:69); *dàx-it mára?*<|> What are you saying? (A7:14).
(2) **how could it be?** | *nàša*<|> *dàx la-pălə́nna?*<|> Man, how could it be that I shall not divide them? (A1:13); *mə́re dàxi?*<|> He said ‘How could that be?’

(3) **like, as** | Before clause or noun (with pronominal suffixes: *daxwaθe*): *dáx ṱ-in-muθɛ́θəlla ʾa-béna xèta,*<|> *ʾay-béna ʾàna maθyánna*<|> Just as I brought her before, so this time I shall bring her (A27:30); *dax-ṱ-íwət ʾáti hátxa mṣuqàlta,*<|> *ʾap-ʾáw daxwàθax-ile*<|> Just as you are pretty, so he is like you (A8:67); *qa-t-là-hawe sɛ́rga spáy dax-d-áw*<|> so that there will not be another saddle as fine as it (A8:37).

(4) **when** | *dax-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla θàya,*<|> *hádəx ṣràxa-w*<|> *xumθàne,*<|> *Čúxo rìqɛle,*<|> *plíṭɛle gu-màθa*<|> When he saw them coming, shouting and angry, Čuxo ran out into the village (A7:16).
(5) Idioms: *dàx lítlux xáṭər*<|> By all means (I’ll do as you say) (A21:11).

meanings: (1) With imperatives and deontic verbs: *də-mjămə́xlən jarrèta*<|> Let’s put together a food-box for ourselves (A30:41); *də-šqúl ʾanna-zùze!*<|> Take these coins! meanings: (1) **almost, about to** | Combined with verb: *ga-ṱ-àθən*<|> I am about to come; *ga-máṭya ṱ-axlàle*<|> She is about to eat him (A18:26).

(2) **connective particle** | Signalling temporal sequentiality: *rắpili m-an-képe ṱ-íla tàma,*<|> *ga-maxzə́nnux ʾúrxa ṣàlət*<|> Throw me the stones that are there, then I shall show you the way down (A14:70). Introducing a comment: *lá-məre bắye xàθux.*<|> *mə́re bắye Zìne.*<|> *ga-ʾɛ́ni Zìne*<|> *ʾáxni lɛ̀ðəx.*<|> He did not say ‘He loves your sister.’ He said ‘He loves Zine.’ Now, we do not know (by this statement) which Zine (was meant) (A26:61). At the beginning of direct speech, predominantly questions: *ʾámər ga-k̭òra*<|> *ʾána mò yánnux?*<|> He said ‘Now, blind man, what can I give you?’ (A26:57); *mə́ra ga-mo-xə̀ðye b-áwwa dúša?*<|> They said ‘Why are we so happy about this honey?’ (A14:15).

examples: *málla Naṣrádin xá-ga băyéwa mbašə́lwa pàča*<|> Once mullah Naṣradin wanted to cook pača (A5:1); *xa-xá-ga* (B6:16), *xa-xa-gáye* (B15:77), *gá-gaθa* sometimes; *b-xšàwən*<|> *ʾáyya quṣàrta*<|> *hár gărəg-máṭe ʾəllì-xa-ga*<|> I think this cooking pot should eventually belong to me (A5:2); *tré-gaye tré wíta ʾàrba*<|> Two times two equals four; *xámša gáye xámša wáyɛla ʾə́sri-w xàmša*<|> Five times five is twenty-five; *raba gayaθa* many times; *ʾo-gáya qằmɛθa θélux l-kə́sli*<|> The first time you came to me ... (A1: 22). *xa-ga xeta* another time, again: *xá-ga xéta plíṭṭɛla Lelìθa*<|> Again Leliθa came out’ (A51:12); then: *bắye qaṭə̀lwale.*<|> *xá-ga xéta klèle*<|> He wanted to kill him. Then he refrained (A10:3-4). *ʾɛ-ga* at that time, then | *ʾɛ́-ga zúze baṣòrewa.*<|> At that time money was scarce (B5:5); *kút-dana ʾa-ṣə́pra mìtle,*<|> *ʾɛ́-ga ʾana-mɛ̀θən*<|> If ever that sparrow dies, then I shall die (A12:41); *là-palṭət,*<|> *hal-t-̭amrə́nnux plùṭgena*<|> *ʾɛ̀-ga pálṭət*<|> Do not come out, until when I say to you ‘Come out!’, at *that* time you should come out (A14:67). Governing a temporal clause: *ʾɛ́-gət damə̀xwa,*<|> *ṭḷaθà yomáθa*<|> *ʾu-ṭḷaθà lɛlăwáθa háwe dmìxa*<|> When he slept, he would be asleep for three days and three nights (A29:2). Expressing logical sequence: *ʾɛ́-ga ʾáp-ana bắyən ʾàzən*<|> So, I also want to go (A5:1). Governing a factual conditional (§19.5.8.): *ʾɛ́-gət mən-d-ánna hàwe,*<|> *šúla bṱ-ázəl la-qàma!*<|> If there are these (gold pieces), the job will go ahead! (A4:15).

meanings: (1) **thus, like that** | *dax-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla θàya,*<|> *hádəx ṣràxa-w*<|> *xumθàne,*<|> *Čúxo rìqɛle*<|> When he saw them coming, shouting like this and angry, Čuxo ran away (A7:16); *páyəšwa ʾax-xàlwa,*<|> *brìza hádəx*<|> It would become like curds, dry, (it was) like that (B7:22).

(2) **the same** | *dártət-yoma zílla wídla hàdəx*<|> The next day she went and did the same (A18:3); *xàrθa,*<|> *pàlṭeti*<|> *ʾap-ʾaṣə́rta hàdəx*<|> Then, you go out, and in the evening (do) the same (A22:23); *har-hádəx ʾŭ́mur Már Qiyòma*<|> The age of Mar Qiyoma is the same (B1:7).

(3) Making temporal intervals in narrative: *šə́ryela gu-d-ɛ́ ʾotél ʾo-yòma-w*<|> *píšela hàdəx,*<|> *ʾaṣə́rta θìθɛla*<|> *bắyi ṱ-áxli xa-ràmša*<|> They put up in the hotel that day and remained like that (until) the evening came and they wanted to eat dinner (A2:2); *xa-béna wítɛla hádəx b-lɛ̀le*<|> *mə́xyɛle taq-taq-táq l-tằra*<|> Then, at night, there was a knock at the door (A23:26); *bar-hàdəx,*<|> *y-aθɛ́wa mdarɛ̀wale*<|> *qa-t-lá-hawa píše šə̀xte*<|> Then they would come and winnow it (B5:86); *hádəx ʾáp-ati ʾə̀θyət*<|> Meanwhile you also came (A2:9).

(4) **so much** | *ʾo-xáwri hádəx gabbàra,*<|> *xázəx wírre gawàye*<|> We saw my friend, who was such a huge man, go inside (B15:58); *hàdəx-iwa xóš-naša*<|> *hàdəx-iwa spày*<|> He was such a good man, he was so good (A4:31).

examples: *hadíya ðíli ʾána manáy díyux mòdila*<|> Now I know what you mean (A17:35); *díya lɛ̀kət zála?*<|> Now where are you going? (A1:12); *ʾána m-díya m-bàθər*<|> *brátux băyə̀nna*<|> I from now on love your daughter (A17:35); *dìya*<|> *t-xzéle málka dúnye ráya pàṛe*<|> *zawn-šlàmɛle*<|> Now that the king has seen it raining lambs, it is the time of peace (A1:26); *ʾu-díya ṱ-àθyən*<|> I shall be right back (A4:22); *har-díya máṭyən ṱ-àθyən*<|> I shall go right now and come back (A4:17); *díya b-dìya*<|> (A30:28), *di-b-dìya*<|> right now (A30:35).

(literally: Blue on your condition!) (A23:10).

(pl. *hawāl*) (A.) **condition, situation** | *hā́l hawā́l ʾàtxɛla*<|> The situation is like this (A8:35); *hā́l ʾu-hawā́l hátxa xzèli*<|> I saw such-and-such things (A4:7); *hā́l-u qə́ṣṣət hàtxɛla*<|> The situation is like this (A12:42); *ʾána háli m-halɛ̀xu*<|> I shall live like you (A14:97); *líθ wíya čù-məndi,*<|> *genáwe hàle?*<|> Has anything happened? (literally: Blue on your condition!) (A23:10).

meanings: (1) **until, up to** | *hal-ʾaṣə́rta plìxɛle*<|> He worked until evening (A16:5); *ʾo-mənnɛ́xu t-dàqər*<|> *b-Mằmo,*<|> *m-áxxa hál qaṣrət-mìra*<|> *ṱ-oðə́xle də̀mma*<|> Whoever of you touches Mămo, we shall scatter his blood from here until the palace (A26:68); *yáʿni xamšá daqíqela hal-ʾə̀ṣra*<|> *ʾáti ʾàθeti*<|> after five or ten minutes you should come back (A22:22); *hal-ʾìman ṱ-áwət hátxa mdagóle?*<|> For how long will you lie like this? (A26:56). Before a prepositional phrase: *wíyəx pláša m-ʾaṣə́rta hal-gu-mbadlàθa*<|> We fought from evening until morning (A12:19); *hal-gu-réšət ṭúra* up to the top of the mountain (A14:49). Combined with connective particle *w*: *m-ó-yoma dwíqəlle Mắmo gu-hàbsa,*<|> *ʾu-hàl-ʾədyo*<|> From that day he has held Mămo in prison, until today (A26:75); *kùllən,*<|> *mən-yále zóre ʾu-hal-gòṛe*<|> all of us, from young children to old people (B16:4). Content clause as complement (often shortened to *ha-*): *zílela hal-mə́ṭyela l-qàṣra*<|> They went until they arrived at the palace (A24:49); *kazíwa práməlla har-palṭìwa,*<|> *hál plíṭla hàtxa*<|> They tried to cut them down, but they kept growing up, until they grew like this (A38:15); *mxéla l-ġðàðe*<|> *ha-t-ṭḷáθna mìtla*<|> They beat one another until the three of them died (A22:35).
(2) **before** | *ha-ṱ-íle ʾə̀θya,*<|> *mpuláṭṭɛla fằqih*<|> Before he came back, she took out the jurist (A22:39); *pɛšáwa tàlga hal-qedámta*<|> It would become ice before morning (B15:26).
(3) **until when** | *là-palṭət,*<|> *hal-ṱ-amrə́nnux plùṭgena*<|> *ʾɛ̀-ga pálṭət*<|> Do not come out, until when I say to you ‘Come out!’, at that time you should come out (A14:67).

meanings: (1) **also** | *ʾap-m-d-áni y-óði muràbba,*<|> *yáʿni ham-mən-sparə̀gle*<|> They make jam also from these, that is also from quinces (B5:219).
(2) **even** | in conditional constructions: *hám-ʾən yawə́tli zùze,*<|> *lè-y-aθən*<|> Even if you give me money, I shall not come.
(3) **again** | *ham-zílɛle kə́sle dìye*<|> He went again to him (A25:25); *ham-mṣawòre ʾə́lle díye*<|> He curses him again (A17:3).

examples: *kəmɛ́le ḥàqqe?*<|> What is its price?| *ʾáxni šáqləx ḥáqqət ʾəjàra mə́nne díye*<|> We shall receive wages from him (A14:15); *ʾu-la-ḥáqqət kàrmi lɛle-yáwa*<|> nor does he pay the price of the orchard (A17:30).
raw_entry: *ḥaqq* n.m. (A.) **price; wage** | *kəmɛ́le ḥàqqe?*<|> What is its price?| *ʾáxni šáqləx ḥáqqət ʾəjàra mə́nne díye*<|> We shall receive wages from him (A14:15); *ʾu-la-ḥáqqət kàrmi lɛle-yáwa*<|> nor does he pay the price of the orchard (A17:30).

examples: *ʾu-haqquθɛ́xu le-y-ṭàlqa*<|> Your right will not be lost (A8:88); *ʾína ʾítli ḥaqqùθi*<|> but I (must) have my fee (A27:19); *ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa*<|> *ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa*<|> I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5); *xále díye t-ḥaqqùθa*<|> His real uncle (A23:28).
raw_entry: *ḥaqquθa* n.f. (A.) **right; fee; what is lawful** | *ʾu-haqquθɛ́xu le-y-ṭàlqa*<|> Your right will not be lost (A8:88); *ʾína ʾítli ḥaqqùθi*<|> but I (must) have my fee (A27:19); *ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa*<|> *ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa*<|> I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5); *xále díye t-ḥaqqùθa*<|> His real uncle (A23:28).

trans: **always; again; still; as soon as; directly; just, only; the same; surely** (§15.11.).
meanings: (1) **always, constantly** | *har-bxàya-wawa*<|> They were constantly continued crying (A25:5); *ʾu-ʾáti har-háwət baràye*<|> *ʾu-sáprət ku-t-áθe làxxa*<|> You be outside all the time and wait for whoever comes here (A22:23); *har-blígət b-kàsux*<|> You are always busy with your stomach (A23:10).
(2) **again** | *yómət ṭḷàθa*<|> *har-ṣlèla*<|> On the third day she went down again (A22:18).

(3) **still** | Temporal persistence: *ʾu-dəbbóre hár-hola qam-tắrət bòya*<|> The hornets were still before the door of the hole (A20:9); *har-xáθe ʾi-bằyela*<|> He still loves his sister (A18:16); *ʾáy har-là-yawəlla*<|> It still does not give it back (A34:4); *hal-lɛle* < *har-lɛle*: *hal-lɛ̀la gláya*<|> She (the mother) still does not reveal (the truth) (A38:6). Logically unexpected: *kəmə̀t ṱ-árqena*<|> *tópe har-ṭapyàli*<|> However much I run, a gun will still reach me (B9:3).

(4) **as soon as** | *har-ðìlɛxu príqlən mən-ṭúra,*<|> *dɛ́rən tòpe,*<|> *kút-xa maxèla*<|> *xánjər dìye,*<|> *ʾo-ṱ-íle qáme díye qaṭə̀lle*<|> As soon as you know that we have finished (coming over) the mountain, I shall fire a gun and everyone will strike with his dagger and kill the man in front of him (B19:6); *har-qítla bìyux,*<|> *qaṭlílux ṱ-axlìlux*<|> As soon as they hit you, they will kill you and eat you (A22:39).
(5) **directly** | *har-ʾə́θyɛle mən-ṭúra réša-reša d-o-gàre*<|> He came straight from the mountain onto the roof (A23:14).

(6) **just, only** | *har-ʾàna hon-zlíma*<|> Only I am wronged (A13:5); *lá har-ʾáxni zlìme*<|> Not only we are wronged (A13:16); *har-ʾàwwɛle*<|> He is alone (A17:16); *har-ʾàti*<|> you yourself (and nobody else) (A27:6); *hár-xa xále dìyele*<|> It is his one and only uncle (A28:11). Narrowing the extent of an action: *ʾína bróna lɛ̀la xíltəlle.*<|> *har-nobáltəlle muttɛ́θəlle mattòye.*<|> She did not eat the boy. She just took him and put him down. (A19:7); *ʾána har-ṣálən mðìta*<|> *mɛ́θən ʾixàla*<|> *ʾu-ʾàθena*<|> I’ll just go down to the town to bring food and come back (A26:30).
(7) **the same** | in combination with demonstratives: *hàr ʾo-yóma* on the same day (A25:4).

(8) **surely, indeed** | *ʾáxni har-xònən-it*<|> You are indeed our brother (A39:12); *ʾay-xá-yoma har-t-yằða*<|> *ṱ-íle míθa brònən*<|> She will surely know one day that our son is dead (A4:39)

meanings: (1) **still** | *héš xúya xùyɛle*<|> It is still very dark (A30:36); *ʾáy heš-hóla gu-gòma*<|> She is still in the basement stable (A18:22). As an intensifier of a comparative: *heš-bìš qam-xóna díya qímtɛla*<|> She rose still earlier than her brother (A8:69); *b-qáryən ʾu-hèš-biš záwda*<|> I shall call yet louder (A8:72).

(2) *heš* + negator = **not yet** | *heš-lɛ́le làxxa*<|> He is not here yet; *heš-lɛ́le ʾə̀θya*<|> He has not come yet; *š-lɛ́wa mšúrya xála gə̀lla*<|> It had not yet started to eat grass (B5:175); *qəm-dári ʾan-dáwwe heš-t-là bráza*<|> They have poured out the *dawwe* while it is not yet dry (B14:1).

(3) *la* + *heš* (generally contracted to *leš, lɛš, laš, ləš*) = **no longer** | *léš-ʾaθəx hayorə̀xlux*<|> We shall no longer come to help you (A48:6); *leš faydáləx qáṭlət gànəx*<|> It will no longer be of any use to you to kill yourself (A38:16); *ʾáqlət susɛ́xu ʾən-píšla kèpa,*<|> *léš maṣítu jawjìtu*<|> If the legs of your horses have become stone, you will no longer be able to move (A8:28); *léš-ile gu-bɛ̀θa*<|> He is no longer in the house; *lɛ́š-in xzàya*<|> I can no longer see (A24:2).

trans: **how many/much? some, several; so much/many; however much, as much as; when; as for** (§14.9.9., §19.3.5.)
meanings: (1) **how many? how much?** (interrogative) | *ʾína kəmà-gaye zíllux ʾu-šqíllux ʾáyya?*<|> How many times have you gone and taken it? (B15:90); *ʾawwa ʾaskaríya dìye*<|> *ṭlà-kəma dánɛla?*<|> For what time is this army of his for? Used independently: *kəmà t-yátli?*<|> How much will you give me? (A24:5). Used predicatively: *sáʾət kəmɛ̀la?*<|> The time is how much? (= What time is it?) (A26:27). Adverb: *kəmà zonə́tle?*<|> For how much will you buy him? (A24:23).
(2) **some, several** | *kə́ma gàye*<|> several times (B9:18); *y-oráwa kə́ma yàrxe*<|> Several months passed (B5:18).

(3) **so much, so many** (exclamatory) | *ʾána kəmà dána ṱ-in-mṣalóye ṭla-márya ʾàlaha*<|> *ta-t-yawə́lli ʾə̀mma dáwe*<|> I was praying to the Lord God so many times to give me a hundred gold coins (A6:10); *kəma-basìmtɛla ʾixála!*<|> The food is so delicious! (A21:31). Adverb: *baxtáθa kə́ma zădíwa mən-xuwwàwe!*<|> The women feared snakes so much! (B5:78). Governing a clause (usually abbreviated to *ma*): *ʾánna ma-ṱ-íla xmíle b-ġðàðe!*<|> How happy they were together! (A4:50); *ʾu-ṭə̀lyela*<|> *ma-t-wáwa kčìxe*<|> They slept, so tired were they (A14:43).

(4) **however much, as much as** (governing a clause) | *kəmə̀t ṱ-árqena*<|> *tópe har-ṭapyàli*<|> However much I run, a gun will still reach me (B9:3); *xúl kəma-t-bằyət*<|> Eat as much as you want (B15:56).
(5) **when** | *ma-t-wéwa brōn-málka qə́ryəlle ʾo-kθàwa,*<|> *mə́re spày!*<|> When the son of the king had read the letter, he said ‘Good!’ (A11:18).
(6) **as for** | *kəmá ṱ-íle Rùstam,*<|> *ʾáw mbaqórəlle Tătár-i Slemán-i Sə̀ndi*<|> As for Rustam, he asked for Tătar-i Sleman-i Səndi (A28:24).

meanings: (1) **at/to the home/presence of** | *čídət kəslɛ̀ni*<|> You are invited to our home (A22:14). Frequently after verbs of movement: *zílle kəs-màlka*<|> He went to the king (A17:31); *xa-yála hóle ʾə́θya táma kəslèy*<|> a young man has come to their home (A17:21); *θíθɛla koðə́nta kə̀sli*<|> The mule came up to me (B5:132); *ʾáni kə́lye kəs-bɛ̀θa*<|> They all stayed at home (A39:12).
(2) **to (an object)** after verbs of movement | *ríqle kəs-d-à ʾilána*<|> He ran to the tree (A14:27), *qrúla qrúla kə́sle dìye*<|> They came near to it (A14:42).
(3) **with** | *dmíxɛle kəs-báxtət ʿAbda-Raḥmā̀n-bēk*<|> He slept with the wife of ʿAbda-Raḥmān-bēk (A23:26).
(4) **next to, by** | *múttəlla kəs-d-ó Kărim-addìn*<|> He put it next to Karimaddin (A14:31); *mattátla xa-kawázət míya kəs-réša-w bàs*<|> Put out for her a jar of water by her head (A21:7).

trans: **to, for, upon, at, by:** Admominal uses
meanings: (1) Destination: *si-dúṛ l-šòpux*<|> Go back to your place (A15:20).
(2) Objective without movement: *ʾálaha šuxa-l-šə́mme* God—praise be to his name (A6:10).
(3) **upon**: *hóle tíwa l-kèpa*<|> He is sitting on a stone (A15:13); occasionally with the form *ʾal-*: *ʾal-ʾằra*<|> on the ground (A21:5).

(4) General spatial location: *hóle ʾàrya*<|> *l-àyya góta*<|> *ʾu-ʾə̀zza*<|> *hóla l-àyya góta*<|> There is lion on this side and a she-goat on the other side (A24:15); *hóla spára l-kàwe*<|> They are waiting at the window (A4:59).
(5) Expression of the agent: *šáwwaθna hóla xíle l-dèwa*<|> The seven of them have been eaten by wolves (A23:15).
(6) Combined with other prepositions: *ʾo-gáya qằmɛθa θélux l-kə́sli*<|> The first time you came to me (A1:22). Use of *l-* + pronominal suffixes:
(1) Inflection of past verbal base: *qṭille* He killed (him), *zille* He went.
(2) Direct and indirect object: *qaṭəlle* He kills him; *hawəlle* He gives to him.
(3) Possession: *ʾitli kθawa* I have a book. Use of *ʾəll-* + pronominal suffix:
(1) Destination: *ʾə́θyela mə́ṭye ʾə̀lle*<|> They came up to him (A7:19);
(2) Direction (without movement), beneficiary: *ʾámər ʾə́lla dìya*<|> He says to her (A16:7); *wídla fṭárta ʾə̀lli*<|> She made me breakfast (A21:38).
(3) on (surface): *mattí ʾíða ʾə̀lle*<|> They place a hand on it (B5:100); *qímle murə́sle hátxa míya ʾəllèy*<|> He sprinkled water on them like this (B6:11).
(4) over (abstract relation): *hótu pšàma ʾə́lla díya*<|> You are sad over it (A5:10).
(5) direct object (bound to verb): *múttətəlle* You put him (A22:39); *prìmənəlla* I cut it (f.) (A22:9).

examples: *ṣə̀lyela*<|> *swánət ʾúmra la-qámθa díya ràmta-wawa*<|> They (the sheep) went down over the eaves of the church, the front side of which was high (B18:6). Used mainly in adverbial expressions: *la-qáma* forwards; *la-bára* backwards; *kú mənná ṱ-íle pláṭa mən-gawàye,*<|> *pláṭa la-qam-tằra*<|> Each one who goes out from inside, going towards the outside (B11:8); *y-azíwa la-zràqət yóma*<|> They would go in the direction of the rising of the sun (A8:22); *hóle ʾə́θya Déwa Zàr*<|> *... m-la-gnay-yòma*<|> Dewa Zar has come ... from the West (A28:14); *ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa,*<|> *ṱ-áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa*<|> If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come (D2:16); *hola θela m-la-Maye* Look she has come from the direction of Maye (C2:46).
raw_entry: *la* n.f. (K.) **side, direction** | *ṣə̀lyela*<|> *swánət ʾúmra la-qámθa díya ràmta-wawa*<|> They (the sheep) went down over the eaves of the church, the front side of which was high (B18:6). Used mainly in adverbial expressions: *la-qáma* forwards; *la-bára* backwards; *kú mənná ṱ-íle pláṭa mən-gawàye,*<|> *pláṭa la-qam-tằra*<|> Each one who goes out from inside, going towards the outside (B11:8); *y-azíwa la-zràqət yóma*<|> They would go in the direction of the rising of the sun (A8:22); *hóle ʾə́θya Déwa Zàr*<|> *... m-la-gnay-yòma*<|> Dewa Zar has come ... from the West (A28:14); *ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa,*<|> *ṱ-áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa*<|> If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come (D2:16); *hola θela m-la-Maye* Look she has come from the direction of Maye (C2:46).

meanings: (1) **no** | *mə́ra là*<|> *ʾáti ṣli-be-màlka*<|> They said ‘No, you go down to the house of the king’ (A25:87); *mə́re bráti lá là!*<|> He said ‘My daughter, no, no!’ (A21:30); *mə́re làʾ!*<|> He said ‘No!’ (A1:6); *ʾámər làʾa!*<|> He says ‘No!’ (A21:42).

(2) **not** | *la-ṣábrəx ṱ-òrəx*<|> We do not dare enter (A14:40); *lə́mu la-qìmlux?*<|> Why did you not stand? (A26:48); *bróni là qəṭlúle!*<|> Do not kill my son! (A33:6); *ʾána lɛ̀-gorən,*<|> *la-ʾàti gáwrət*<|> I shall not marry, so long as you do not marry (A25:83); *ʾáni maṣlə́xwa ʾə̀rxe,*<|> *ṭaxnə̀xwala,*<|> *là kúlla náše*<|> *bas-ʾàxni*<|> ‘We brought them down to the water-mill and ground them, not everybody, but we did (this) (B10:88). Negating an adjective: *fə́lfəl ... là-xšilta* uncrushed pepper (B10:21).

(3) *la ... la* **neither ... nor** | *ʾána làn dmíxa,*<|> *là-b-lele,*<|> *là-b-yoma*<|> I have not slept, neither at night nor during the day (A24:24); *ʾána lànwa wíða*<|> *là xarbayúθa*<|> *là spayúθa ṭla-čú-naša*<|> I have done neither evil nor good to anybody (A14:23); *lá-băyəx la-mìya*<|> *ʾu-la-čù-məndi*<|> We want neither water nor anything else (A39:12).
(4) **asseverative particle** | *la-hóle mìθa*<|> He is indeed dead (A17:2); A: *štélux čàyux?*<|> B: *la-štèli!* A: Have you drunk your tea? B: Indeed I have drunk it!

examples: Idioms: *yawa ləbba l-* to console (after death), to encourage: *híwɛle lə́bba ṭla-g*ʸ*áne dìye*<|> He took heart (A8:58). *ləbbi zille l-d-ɛ qumta* I fainted at the sight of that figure (C2:55). *bəd-lə́bba gu-bɛ́θət bába dìyɛla*<|> She thinks that she is in her father’s house (A21:18). *gu-lə́bbe díye mtuxmə̀nne*<|> I thought to himself (A39:5). *lə́bbe biyáxu tlìqetu*<|> He thinks you are lost (A14:85). *dwiqále b-lə̀bbe*<|> He kept it in mind. *ʾáyya quṣárta ràba šapirta,*<|> *rába zála ləbbì-ʾəlla*<|> This cooking pot is very nice, I like it a lot (A5:2); *hóle zála lə̀bbi*<|> *ṱ-ásqət ṣɛ́dət ʾə́rbət wàla*<|> I would like you to go up and hunt for wild sheep (A26:44). *lə́bbi basìma*<|> I am happy. *ʾáwwa náša lə́bbe pqìle*<|> The heart of that burst (= He was terrified) (A32:2). *qìdle lə́bbi,*<|> *xóni zòra-wewa*<|> My heart yearned (for him), he was my young brother (A34:24); *mən-lə́bbe díye qìða,*<|> *dɛ́re xɛ̀la,*<|> *načə̀lle ʾo-šəryóxa*<|> Out of his fervour, he applied force and pulled the tether apart (A28:20). *xílli lə̀bbux*<|> My dear, you are dear to me (A39:12). *ʾána hóle píša lə̀bbi*<|> I am angry. *t-la-páyəš lə́bbən b-ġðàðe*<|> so that we do not feel anger at each other (B5:10); *ṭḷàθna*<|> *xonăwáθət Qára Tèždin*<|> *mopíšəlle ləbbèy*<|> The three brothers of Qara Teždin became angry (A26:71). *ʾánna píšla gu-lə́bbe díye kùlla*<|> All these (words) weighed on his heart (A38:13). *ʾáyya lɛ̀ða,*<|> *lə́bba ṣə̀pya žáre*<|> She did not know, she was innocent, poor thing (A14:99). *hátxa baṣlóṣe gu-lə́bbət nàša*<|> (They) glow in the heart of man (= they captivate one’s heart) (A8:16). *m-kúlla lə́bbi bắyən ʾána qaṭlìtuli*<|> With all my heart I want you to kill me (B9:14).

annotations: variants: *liθən, liθena, liθga, liθgən, liθgena*. past: *liθwa*
meanings: (1) Used without suffixes | *líθ čù-məndi*<|> There is nothing (A21:5); *líθ ʾáp-xa gu-bɛ̀θa?*<|> Is there nobody in the house? (A22:32); *čú-qala líθən mənnèy*<|> There is no sound of them (A18:15); *ʾɛ́-ga líθwa bə̀rqa*<|> At that time there was not electricity (B10:45); *líθwa qá-t mbaqríwa bràta*<|> It was not the practice to ask the girl (B5:2). Used interrogatively to draw attention to a particular point: *ʾo-šúla ʾáwwa y-amrə́xwale qə̀rṭa líθən?*<|> We called this job trimming, you see (B5:141).

(2) With L-suffixes expressing possession: *ʾána zúza lìtli*<|> I do not have money. (A22:19); *lítle la-bába la-yə́mma la-ʾàp-xa*<|> He does not have a father, a mother or anybody (A17:17); *lìθwale quṣə̀rta*<|> He did not have a cooking-pot (A5:1); *lítla xàm*<|> That’s fine, no problem.

examples: *xúwwe mà ṱ-áwəð b-an-álpa dáwe?*<|> What will the snake do with those thousand gold coins? (A1:8); *xáθi mà-ləx?*<|> Sister, what is the matter with you? (A34:12); *mà-lux zə́dya?*<|> Why are you afraid? (A11:6); *má-lux mə́nne ʾàti?*<|> What business is it of yours? (A32:3); *ʾána má-li mə̀nnux?*<|> What have I to do with you? (A32:22); *má-ləx bráta ṱ-it-hátxa bxàya*<|> What is the matter with you girl that you are weeping so much? (A34:20); *sállət míya yắðət mɛ̀la?*<|> (< *mà-ila*) Do you know what a basket of water is? (A16:10). Modifier of a noun: *ʾánna ma-brinànela gu-réšux*<|> What wounds are these on your head? (A29:6). Exclamatory modifier of a noun: *ʾu-Bə́lbəl Hazár yăðátla ma-báxta xàmθɛla*<|> You know what a beautiful woman Bəlbəl Hazar is (A8:65). Expressing an exclamatory proposition: *ma-píštət k̭awə̀lla!*<|> How you have become a ruin! (A18:16). With remonstrating force in negated questions *ma-lat-ðáya b-gánəx qàrθɛla?*<|> Don’t you know yourself that it is cold?! (A20:1). Before imperatives: *ma-yəmmi pɛli zwaðe* Mother, bake me supplies! (A50:9). Before a repeated noun to express a more general class (§14.11.): *jawə́tta ṭla-pràma*<|> *ʾanna qɛ́se ma-qɛ̀se*<|> A chopper was for chopping wood and the like (B5:141).

meanings: (1) Separation or removal: *šqíləlla mən-d-ɛ-dɛ̀rta*<|> They took it from that enclosure (A15:12); *nìxlən m-Čúxo*<|> We are relieved of Čuxo (A7:19).
(2) Source or origin: *ʾən-k*ʸ*álo m-gu-màθa,*<|> *čɛrxìwala máθa*<|> *xáṣə dawɛ̀re*<|> If the bride was from the village, they would take her round the village on the back of mules (B10:34).
(3) Temporal starting point: *ʾu-hóla mšuyðánta mən-d-ó-yoma ṱ-íla xzíθəlle ʾàw*<|> She has been mad from the day that she saw him (A4:12).
(4) Partitive: *šqíltɛla mən-dàwe*<|> She took some of the gold coins (A10:7).
(5) Comparison: *ʾína mástət ʾə́rwe rába biš-basimtɛ́la biš-príštɛla mən-d-a-t-tàwre*<|> But the yoghurt of sheep is much better and more choice than that of cattle (B5:173).
(6) Cause: *ʾána-ži m-kɛ́rbi ʾə́θyən ʾá-kθɛθa múttənna rəš-núra ʾu-xìlənna*<|> I, out of my anger, came and put the chicken on the fire and ate it (A2:11).
(7) Material: *məlxáwa ʾíwa mtúrṣa m-qɛ̀sa*<|> The winnowing fork was made from wood (B5:87).
(8) Stative spatial location: *ʾasṛíwala b-qɛ́sa ʾu-m-áy-gota qɛ̀sa*<|> *ʾu-m-áy-gota qɛ̀sa*<|> They would bind them to a stick, with a stick this side and a stick that side (B7:16).
(9) Comitative: *mən-xuráne díye píšɛle gu-ṭúra xá-yoma yóme trè*<|> With his friends he remained in the mountains one or two days (A4:2).

(10) Combined with other prepositions: *ʾu-ṭríðəlle m-gu-bɛ̀θa*<|> He drove him from the house (A16:11); *xa-qála ʾáθe m-qam-tắrət bɛ̀θa*<|> A voice came from before the house (A22:29); *ʾázən šáqlən zùzi*<|> *m-rəš-ʾɛ̀na*<|> I shall go to take my money from on top of the spring (A15:2).

trans: **what; why?; how could it be? how (exclamatory).**
meanings: (1) **what** | Interrogative: *mò-băyət?*<|> What do you want? (A13:13); *mòdi wídle?*<|> What did he do? (A25:19); *mú bṱ-àwe?!*<|> What will it be? (= That is fine, OK) (A18:33); *mo-ʾìba?!* What is there in it?! (= That is fine, OK) (A13:1); *màw-lux?*<|> What is the matter with you? (A31:9); *mút qála dìyi?*<|> What is my voice? (A25:44). Indirect question: *xáze mòdila qə́ṣṣət*<|> He sees what the problem is (A22:43); *làn-ðaʾa mo-qaríwale*<|> I do not know what they call him (A12:20); *ṱ-ázən xázən mòdi píše ʾan-náše*<|> I shall go to see what has become of those people (A18:12). Modifier of a noun: *ʾáwwa mò-tăhər nášɛle?*<|> What kind of man is he? (A25:31); *ʾáyya mòdi mðítɛla?*<|> What town is this? (A26:26). Exclamatory: *ʾína mù-brata!*<|> But what a girl! (A13:11). Head of a relative clause: *mšaróyela kθàwa*<|> *bɛθwáθət nàše*<|> *ʾu-mo-ṱ-itlèy*<|> They start registering the houses of people and what they have (B1:16).

(2) **why?** | *mu-ṣṭímlux bɛ̀θi?*<|> Why have you ruined me? (literally: Why have you destroyed my house?) (A15:14); *mút ʾáti tíwta làxxa?*<|> Why are you sitting here? (A25:58); *módit ʾə̀θya?*<|> Why have you come? (A17:31).

(3) **how could it be?** | questioning possibility of sth., mainly with short forms *mu-, mut*: *ʾánna šáwwa yamàθa*<|> *ʾana mù pɛðə́nna?*<|> How could I cross these seven seas? (A12:26); *mùt hole-pč̣íla?*<|> How could it be that it is crooked? (A17:20); *mut-yằðən ʾɛ́kɛla?*<|> How shall I know where she is? (A14:98).
(4) **how (exclamatory)** | Before a verb: *téla mo-ṭréle ʾə̀lla!*<|> How the fox ran to it! (A49:4).

meanings: (1) Recipient, objective or beneficiary: *mə́re qa-yə́mme dìye*<|> ‘He said to his mother’ (A21:10); *ʾáp-awwa šaqə́lla ðá-kista qa-d-ày,*<|> *yawə́lla qa-d-ày*<|> He takes a purse for her and gives it to her (A4:22); *qa-mo? qa-modi?* why?
(2) Destination: *núbləlla qa-bráte dìye*<|> He took them to his daughter (A17:13).
(3) Temporal objective: *qa-ṭḷà-yarxe*<|> for three months (A17:22).
(4) Object marker: *băyéwa qa-ʾalàha*<|> ‘He loved God’ (A16:10).

(5) Before a clause expressing purpose or result: *ṣráxɛle qa-t-šằma*<|> *brátət màlka*<|> He is shouting so that the daughter of the king hears (A21:16); *qímle b-zdáya m-bróne dìye*<|> *qa-t-là-ʾamər*<|> He was afraid of his son and (as a result) did not tell (= He was afraid to tell his son) (A8:17).

trans: **before (spatial and temporal); in (adversity), from (adversity); on account of (adversity); instead of.**
meanings: (1) **before (spatial)** | *qam-ʾɛ́nux*<|> before your eyes (A15:15). Obstacle: *muttɛ́θətwa qámi xa-ṭúrət skinyàθa*<|> You had placed before me a mountain of knives (A24:33), *hálli xá-məndi ṱ-àxlən*<|> *t-lá-pɛšən kə́twa qam-ʾàqlux*<|> Give me something to eat so that I am not a thorn in your foot (A26:57). Duty: *ʾána ʾíθ šùla qámi*<|> I have a job to do (A24:45). Outside: *qam-tăra* outside the door (of the house), *qámət gə̀ppa*<|> outside the cave (A12:7). After verbs of movement: *ṱ-azítu qam-d-o-gə̀ppa*<|> You should go to the cave (A8:28), *zíla, zíla zìla,*<|> *qam-xákma ṭuràne*<|> *rába ràme*<|> He went a long way (and came) to some very high mountains (A14:66). At the disposal of, for the benefit of: *ʾáyya dəkkána qàməx*<|> This shop is for you (to choose from as you wish) (A22:20); *ʾáni daríwala qam-qənyàne*<|> They would put them out for the animals (to eat) (B15:50). Leading animals: *xa-šăvána ... y-azə́lwa qam-ʾə̀rwe*<|> A shepherd used to go to look after sheep (A10:1), *qu-sí qam-ʾə̀rwe!*<|> Go and look after the sheep! (A10:5). In charge of: *ṭaxána qam-ðà-ʾarxe*<|> a miller in charge of a water-mill (A32:1).

(2) **before (temporal)** | with a nominal: *qám šáwwi tmáni šə̀nne* seventy or eighty years ago (B5:179); *qam-dàna*<|> beforehand (A4:30); *qam-mxɛ́θət madə̀nxa*<|> before the rise of dawn (A8:51); *ʾáw qam-mə̀nnux hóle ʾə́θya láxxa*<|> He has come back here before you (A22:39). With a clause complement: *qam-ṱ-àθi*<|> *mpáləṭle mən-hàbsa*<|> Before they return, release him from prison (A26:72).

(3) **in (adversity)** | *ʾup-ʾàni*<|> *náše ʾi-xawšìwala*<|> *mattíwale gu-gòme*<|> *qá-t barzìwa,*<|> *qa-t-là-hawiwa qam-mə́ṭra*<|> People would store these (pieces of wood) and put them in the basement to dry, so that they would not be in the rain (B15:19); *ʾəθyewəx kope kope qam-məṭra ʾu-qam dalope* We have come bending down in rain and drizzle (C1:14); *maqðánnux qam-šmàyya*<|> I shall burn you in the sun (A12:31).

(4) **from (adversity)** | In contexts expressing escaping from or sheltering from: *ríqən qam-màmi*<|> I have run away from my paternal uncle (A25:42); *lɛ́ka b-šárṭət qam-ʾiθàθi?*<|> Where can you escape from my hands? (A28:21); *mṭášət qam-Lelìθa*<|> Hide from Leliθa (A51:6); *mṭošéle qam-tàlga*<|> He sheltered from the snow (A28:3).

(5) **on account of (adversity)** | *ʾáskar kúlla mìtla*<|> *qam-qàle*<|> All the army died on account of his voice (A52:13); *šəlmanā̀t*<|> *dìpla*<|> *qam-xɛ̀la*<|> The bars have bent due to the force (put on them) (A52:9); *kšíple bɛ́θa qam-tàlga*<|> The house collapsed on account of the snow; *tréle qam-mə̀ṭra*<|> He was soaked on account of the rain.
(6) **instead of** | *ʾɛ́-ga qam-lámpa ʾíθwa šràʾa*<|> At that time instead of an (electric) lamp there was an (oil) lamp (A33:1).

meanings: (1) **much, a lot, many** | *rába tàlga* much snow (B10:47); *ʾan-yomáθa ṱ-awéwa ràba séra*<|> the days when there was a lot of moonlight (B11:3); *šúla ràba* a lot of work (B5:19); *zúze ràba*<|> a lot of money (A27:18); *líθwa šuláne ràba*<|> There were not many jobs (B11:17). Used independently: *ṭla-d-áy dráyɛla xàčča*<|> *ṭla-d-áw ràba*<|> For herself she pours out a little and for him a lot (A17:25). Intensifier of a verb: *ʾáti ràba băyánnux*<|> I love you a lot (A22:19); *ràba xðéle b-d-a-bràta*<|> ‘He was very happy with the girl’ (A14:96).

raw_entry: *reša* adv. **above; directly** | *ʾáw xá-reša m-táma qú-si l-bɛ̀θa.*<|> He—directly from there get up and go home! (narrative imperatives §15.7.) (A1:19); *ṱ-ázəx xa-rèša*<|> We shall go immediately (B9:15).

meanings: (1) **head (of body)**| *dríθa xə̀ppo b-réša*<|> She had put a veil on her head; *ʾu-mútte párre gu-rèša*<|> They have put feathers on their head (B5:47); *ʾáyya-ži šōp-rèšux-ila*<|> That is the place of your head (A24:51). Referring by synecdoche to whole person: *réšux ṱ-áwe basìma*<|> May you (literally: your head) be healthy (said to a person who has been recently bereaved). In oath: *b-rèšux*<|> *mó ʾamràna?*<|> By your head, what should I say? (A26:33).
(2) **head (of animals)** | *mə́ṭyɛle xa-káwtət ʾə̀rwe,*<|> *ʾíbe tre-ṭḷáθa ʾálpa rēš-ʾə̀rwe*<|> He came to a flock of sheep, in which there were two or three thousand head of sheep (A32:14).
(3) **head person, leader** (pl. *rešane*) | *rešət maθa* village leader.
(4) **head** (**of an instrument)** (pl. *rešaθa*) | *rešət maṛa* the head of spade.
(5) **head (of vegetables)** | *xá-reša tùma*<|> a head of garlic (B10:19).
(6) **round (of cheese)** | Produced by draining in a muslin bag: *šqílli mə́nni qə́ṭṭa m-réšət gùpta*<|> I took with me a piece from the round of cheese.

(7) **top, peak, tip** (pl. *rešăwaθa*) | *ʾilanɛni t-xabušta m-reša-w šətta mnoqašta* Our apple tree is decorated from top to bottom (B8:29); *hóla gu-réšət xa-ṭúra ramàna*<|> She is on the top of a high mountain (A8:21); *xazdə́xwa gəllále gu-rešăwaθa bélən bḗl Turkàye*<|> We would would harvest herbs on the (mountain) tops between us and the Turks; *réšə lišáne* the tip of his tongue (A45:1).
(8) **beginning** | Temporal: *rešət ṣawma* the beginning of the fast. Spatial: *málka tíwa gu-rèšət máθa*<|> The king lived at the top (i.e. beginning) of the village (A25:1).

(9) Idioms: *reša xtaya* upside down; downhill | *réša xtáya kúlle mə̀lxɛle*<|> Down hill it is all salt (A24:12); *ṣlíθɛla reša-xtàya*<|> She went down head first (A8:76); *léwət ʾàti*<|> *ʾɛ-bráta ṱ-in-ʾána wíðəlla gáni k̭óra b-rèšəx*<|> Are you not the girl on account of whom I made myself blind (A16:7); *twíra twíra réše díye m-rēš-d-àyya-wawa*<|> It was because of her that his head was all broken (A29:29); *b-rèšux*<|> (I swear) by your head (that I am telling the truth) (A22:39).

(8) **beginning** | Temporal: *rešət ṣawma* the beginning of the fast. Spatial: *málka tíwa gu-rèšət máθa*<|> The king lived at the top (i.e. beginning) of the village (A25:1). (9) Idioms: *reša xtaya* upside down; downhill | *réša xtáya kúlle mə̀lxɛle*<|> Down hill it is all salt (A24:12); *ṣlíθɛla reša-xtàya*<|> She went down head first (A8:76); *léwət ʾàti*<|> *ʾɛ-bráta ṱ-in-ʾána wíðəlla gáni k̭óra b-rèšəx*<|> Are you not the girl on account of whom I made myself blind (A16:7); *twíra twíra réše díye m-rēš-d-àyya-wawa*<|> It was because of her that his head was all broken (A29:29); *b-rèšux*<|> (I swear) by your head (that I am telling the truth) (A22:39).

meanings: (1) **condition** | *ʾaláha hole-mìra*<|> *t-yawə̀llux*<|> *b-šàrṭ*<|> *kú-mdit yawə̀llux*<|> *ta-šwáwux t-yáwəl trè*<|> God has said that he will give to you on condition that everything he gives to you he will give to your neighbour twofold (A3:4); *šŭrūṭ-díyi mkumlìlux?*<|> Have you fulfilled my conditions? meanings: (1) Recipient, objective or beneficiary: *híwəlla quṣárta ta-màlla*<|> They gave the pot to the mullah (A5:8); *wídla ʾixàla*<|> *ṭla-yàla*<|> She made food for the young man (A21:22). *ṭla-mo, ta-mo, ṭla-modi, ta-modi* why?: *ṭla-mò wídlux hátxa bíyi?*<|> Why (literally: for what) have you done this to me? (A15:14).
(2) Destination: *də́ṛṛa ta-ʾaθrɛ̀y*<|> They returned to their land (A4:27).
(3) Temporal objective: *ʾawwa ʾaskaríya dìye*<|> *ṭlà-kəma dánɛla?*<|> For how long is this army of his? (A17:22).
(4) Object marker: *ʾáwwa qṭìlle ṭla-ʾárya*<|> He killed the lion (A11:1).
raw_entry: *ṭla-, ta-* prep. (with pronominal suffixes: *ṭlale*) **to, for.** (1) Recipient, objective or beneficiary: *híwəlla quṣárta ta-màlla*<|> They gave the pot to the mullah (A5:8); *wídla ʾixàla*<|> *ṭla-yàla*<|> She made food for the young man (A21:22). *ṭla-mo, ta-mo, ṭla-modi, ta-modi* why?: *ṭla-mò wídlux hátxa bíyi?*<|> Why (literally: for what) have you done this to me? (A15:14). (2) Destination: *də́ṛṛa ta-ʾaθrɛ̀y*<|> They returned to their land (A4:27). (3) Temporal objective: *ʾawwa ʾaskaríya dìye*<|> *ṭlà-kəma dánɛla?*<|> For how long is this army of his? (A17:22). (4) Object marker: *ʾáwwa qṭìlle ṭla-ʾárya*<|> He killed the lion (A11:1).

meanings: (1) adj. **other, another** | *mattúli xá-šəmma xèna*<|> Give me another name (A7:2); *m-ya-góta xèta*<|> from the other side (A25:30); *ʾu-mòdi-xenət xə́zya?*<|> What else have you seen? (A17:8). Additional: *ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx*<|> I shall give you another bag like that one (A4:16). Used independently: *xa-xéna* another one (A23:27); *ða-xéta* another one (A22:9); *ʾo-xéna* the other one (A4:45).
(2) **more** | *tálga xèna*<|> more snow; *xákma šə́nne xène*<|> a few more years (B5:208).
(3) adv. **more, again |** *ʾána xéna šúla la-pàlxən*<|> I shall not work any more (A23:40); *xéna ṛìšɛle.*<|> He woke up again (A14:95).

(4) mod. **more** | Modifier of a quantifer: *šqílənwa xáčča xéna qàlya*<|> *ta-ṱ-axlə́nne b-ʾùrxa*<|> I took a little more roasted meat to eat on the way (A23:10); *zmúrrən xánči xèna*<|> Sing to us a little more (A35:8).

(5) **discourse particle** | expressing boundary and prominence: *xéna políse mù ṱ-óði?*<|> Well, what should the police do? (A8:9); *xéna ʾána qɛ́mən ʾázən ʾùmra*<|> Well, I shall go to church (A37:2); *bàssa xéna*<|> Well that is enough (B15:35).

examples: *múttəlla xo-kosìθe*<|> He put them under his hat (A23:6), *tfíqla dàwe xo-ʾáqla díya*<|> She found gold coins under her leg (A10:7); *dɛ́rət ʾíðux xo-d-ò-kepa*<|> Put your hand under that stone (A12:27); *xo-qðala maxmore* with jewels (hanging down) under her neck (C6:4); *ʾáxni xoθ-tagbártət màlkəx*<|> We are under the administration of the king (A8:80). examples: Intensifying negation with remonstrating force: *xo-la-mɛ́θən làxxa*<|> I shall not die here (A20:11); *yába ʾan-ʾə́mma dàwe,*<|> *xu-là mbaqrə̀təlli*<|> Well, do not ask me about those hundred gold coins (A14:65); *xu-lanwa-mírəllux maxzə́tli xăzìna*<|> I had not told you to show me a treasure (A14:23). In negative questions, usually remonstrating: *xo-lat-mírta xà-məndi?*<|> Did you not say something? (= surely you said something?) (A26:34); *bábi tə́mməl ʾáyya mðíta xu-kùmta-wawa?*<|> Father, was this town not black yesterday? (= surely this town was black yesterday) (A4:35). In positive questions: *gúrzə šə́rmux xo-ʾána ṱ-azə́nwa bìya?*<|> Would I be finished off by your stupid club (literally: the club of your behind)?! (A52:17). Introducing apodosis: *ʾən-šắrəṭ díyi qəm-yăðə̀tla,*<|> *xo-b-gawrànnux*<|> If you know (the answer to) my challenge, I shall indeed marry you’ (A25:62); *ʾən-θèli*<|> *xó bàxtiwət*<|> If I come back, then you are my wife (A25:66).

examples: Expressing an increase in quantity: *xá-saʿat biz-zòda*<|> one hour more (B5:54); *mə́ndi zàwda*<|> something more (A3:1); *kùl-məndi bi-záwda*<|> more of everything (A3:3). In estimates of quantity: *ʾəštà yarxé*<|> *xamšà yarxé*<|> *biz-zàwda*<|> five or six months, or more (B5:3). More than: *ʾu-bréle díya b-xšáwən biz-záwda mən-ʾəč̣č̣á-mma ʾálpa nàše*<|> By now there have been born, I think, more than nine-hundred thousand people (B2:10); *záwda mən-ʾarbá-mma šə̀nnele*<|> It is more than four hundred years old (B6:31); *ʾáxni be-Tòməx*<|> *lá-maxəx zóda l-xà*<|> We the family of Toma do not strike more than one (blow) (A52:24). Excessive quantity: *zàwdɛla mə́nni*<|> It is too much for me (to tell) (A26:65). With adverbs: *lá maspərə́xləx bi-zàwda*<|> We shall not make you wait any more (A4:42); *xắyiwa biz-zàwda*<|> They survived longer (B5:190). In combination *sama zawda/zoda* expressing the majority of a set: *xákma har-damxíwa l-ằra*<|> *ʾap-áni gàre.*<|> *ʾína sáma zóda ʾiyɛ́wala qaràwət.*<|> Some would even sleep on the floor of the roof. Most people, however, had a bed. (B5:204); *ʾína sáma zòda*<|> *y-oðíwa ʾằraq*<|> Most people, however, would make arak (B5:213). Idiom: *mìr-e-mən*<|> *zàwdɛla mə́nni,*<|> *ʾána ṱ-amrənnɛ̀xu*<|> *mšáxəlpu dukàne*<|> My lord, may I humbly suggest you change places (Literally: It is too much for me, let me say to you, change places) (A26:65).
